  "article_text": [
    "a complex reflection group @xmath6 on a finite dimensional complex vector space @xmath7 is a subgroup of @xmath8 generated by complex reflections  nontrivial elements that fix a complex hyperplane in @xmath7 pointwise .",
    "finite ( irreducible ) complex reflection groups were classified by shephard and todd  @xcite :    1 .   a general infinite family @xmath9 for positive integral parameters @xmath10 ; 2 .   34 exceptions , labeled @xmath11 .    for the presentations of the above groups , see  @xcite .",
    "finite complex reflection groups are divided into two main classes : primitive and imprimitive .",
    "the general infinite family @xmath9 are imprimitive except @xmath12 and @xmath13 .",
    "( @xmath12 is the symmetric group of degree @xmath14 and @xmath13 is the cyclic group of order @xmath15 . )",
    "the exceptional groups @xmath11 are primitive .",
    "the complex reflection group of type @xmath0 is defined as @xmath16 where @xmath17 is the set of @xmath18-th roots of unity .",
    "special cases of @xmath9 are isomorphic to real reflection groups : @xmath19 , @xmath20 , @xmath21 and @xmath22 , where @xmath23 denotes the coxeter group of type @xmath24 .",
    "for all the other parameters , @xmath9 has no real structure .",
    "the braid group of a complex reflection group is defined as the fundamental group of the regular orbits . for these braid groups ,",
    "the presentations and the centers are shown in  @xcite .",
    "the braid groups @xmath1 of the complex reflection groups @xmath9 are divided into two cases : @xmath25 and @xmath26 . for any @xmath27 , @xmath28  @xcite .",
    "it was shown in  @xcite that the braid groups @xmath29 are garside groups .      in this paper",
    ", we propose new presentations and diagrams for the imprimitive reflection groups @xmath9 and their braid groups @xmath1 for @xmath2 and @xmath30 .",
    "these presentations have much in common with coxeter presentations of real reflection groups .",
    "they are positive and homogeneous , and give rise to quasi - garside structures .",
    "diagram automorphisms correspond to group automorphisms .",
    "to motivate our approach , we review in  [ sec : prelim ] the presentations for the free group @xmath31 and the braid groups @xmath32 and @xmath29 .    as a generic version of the imprimitive reflection groups",
    "@xmath33 , shi  @xcite introduced the complex reflection group @xmath34 and showed that @xmath34 is isomorphic to the affine reflection group of type @xmath35 . in ",
    "[ sec : binfty ] , we propose new presentations for @xmath34 and its braid group @xmath36 .",
    "we show how the braid group @xmath1 is a semidirect product of @xmath37 and an infinite cyclic group , and then show how @xmath9 is a semidirect product of @xmath38 and a cyclic group of order @xmath15 .",
    "the new presentations give rise to quasi - garside structures on the braid groups @xmath37 and @xmath1 .    in  [",
    "sec : geombraid ] , we explore some properties of @xmath1 . elements of @xmath1 will be interpreted as geometric braids on @xmath4 strings whose first string is pure and whose winding number around the first string is a multiple of @xmath5 . using this interpretation , we show that the @xmath39-th root of an element of @xmath1 , if exists , is unique up to conjugacy for any nonzero integer @xmath39 , show that @xmath1 is strongly translation discrete , and classify periodic elements of @xmath1 .",
    "the braid group @xmath36 is isomorphic to @xmath40 . in  [ sec : atilde ] , we propose an @xmath41-type presentation for @xmath1 which is also positive and homogeneous .",
    "_ notations . _",
    "denote by @xmath42 the cyclic product @xmath43 with @xmath39 factors .",
    "for example , @xmath44 and @xmath45 .",
    "if @xmath46 is the word @xmath47 , then we will write @xmath48 as a shorthand for @xmath49 .",
    "here we review the presentations of the free group @xmath31 and the braid group of type @xmath50 .",
    "these presentations are not necessary for the work of this paper , but they will give an intuition about our approach to the braid group @xmath1 .",
    "consider the following two presentations for the free group @xmath31 : @xmath51 the second presentation is obtained from the first one by adding new generators @xmath52 for @xmath53 together with defining relations @xmath54 .",
    "these presentations can be described as in figure  [ fig : freegp](a , b ) . the first diagram is also known as @xmath55 . in the diagram for the second presentation , countably many nodes are tangent to a line labeled 2 , which means the relation @xmath56 for @xmath57 .",
    "it is known that the second presentation gives rise to a quasi - garside structure on @xmath31  @xcite .",
    "one may regard it as a _ dual _ presentation of the first one .",
    "@xmath58 \\begin{xy } ( 0,0 ) * + + = { \\rule{0pt}{4pt } } * \\frm{o } ; ( 20,0 ) * + + = { \\rule{0pt}{4pt } } * \\frm{o}**@{- }   ?     "it is easy to see that the above two presentations are equivalent .",
    "the first presentation is usually referred as the _ classical _ presentation , and the second as the _ dual _ presentation .",
    "both presentations give rise to garside structures .",
    "the free group @xmath31 can be considered as a version of @xmath32 where @xmath5 is replaced by @xmath61 .",
    "brou , malle and rouquier  @xcite obtained the following presentation for the braid group @xmath29 for @xmath62 :    * generators : @xmath63 where @xmath64 ; * relations : the usual braid relations on @xmath65 , along with + @xmath66    furthermore , a presentation for the reflection group @xmath33 is obtained by adding the relation @xmath67 for all generators @xmath68 , and the generators are then all reflections .",
    "the presentation is usually illustrated by the diagram shown in figure  [ fig : beer](a ) .",
    "the diagram is to be read as a coxeter graph for the real reflection group case : when nodes @xmath68 and @xmath69 are joined by an edge labeled @xmath5 , there is a relation @xmath70 ; when nodes @xmath68 and @xmath69 are joined by an unlabelled edge , there is a relation @xmath71 ; when two nodes @xmath68 and @xmath69 are not connected by an edge , there is a relation @xmath72 ; the double line  to 0pt    ' '' ''     between the node @xmath73 and the edge connecting the nodes @xmath74 and @xmath75 indicates the relation @xmath76 .",
    "setting @xmath77 results in the classical presentation of type @xmath50 , and the subpresentation on the generators @xmath78 is the classical presentation of type @xmath79 ( see next subsection ) .",
    "indeed , the subpresentation on the generators @xmath80 is the classical presentation of type @xmath81 .",
    "@xmath82 \\mbox{(a ) brou\\'e - malle - rouquier diagram for $ b(e , e , r)$}\\\\[2 mm ] \\begin{xy } ( -1.7 , 0 ) * { \\ellipse(9,15 ) { } } ; ( 4.2 , 12 ) * + + = { \\rule{0pt}{4pt } } * \\frm{o } ;      ( 20,0 ) * + + = { \\rule{0pt}{4pt } } * \\frm{o } * * @{- } ; ( 4.2,-12 ) * + + = { \\rule{0pt}{4pt } } * \\frm{o } ;      ( 20,0 ) * + + = { \\rule{0pt}{4pt } } * \\frm{o } * * @{- } ; ( 7.1 , 4 ) * + + = { \\rule{0pt}{4pt } } * \\frm{o } ;      ( 20,0 ) * + + = { \\rule{0pt}{4pt } } * \\frm{o } * * @{- } ; ( 7.1,-4 ) * + + = { \\rule{0pt}{4pt } } * \\frm{o } ;      ( 20,0 ) * + + = { \\rule{0pt}{4pt } } * \\frm{o } * * @{- } ; ( 30 , 0 ) * + + = { \\rule{0pt}{4pt } } * \\frm{o } * * @{- } ; ( 40 , 0 ) * + + = { \\rule{0pt}{4pt } } * \\frm{o } * * @{- } ; ( 50 , 0 ) * + + = { \\dots }   * * @{- } ; ( 60 , 0 ) * + + = { \\rule{0pt}{4pt } } * \\frm{o } * * @{- } ; ( -9,0 ) * + + = { 2 } ; ( 9 , 12 ) * + + = { t_1 } ; ( 10,-15 ) * + + = { t_{e-2 } } ; ( 11 , 1 ) * + + = { t_0 } ; ( 11,-7.5 ) * + + = { t_{e-1 } } ; ( 23,-3 ) * + + = { s_3 } ; ( 33,-3 ) * + + = { s_4 } ; ( 43,-3 ) * + + = { s_5 } ; ( 63,-3 ) * + + = { s_r } ; ( 0 , 17.5 ) * + + = { \\cdot } ; ( 1.1 , 17 ) * + + = { \\cdot } ; ( 2 , 16 ) * + + = { \\cdot } ; ( 0 , -17.5 ) * + + = { \\cdot } ; ( 1.1 , -17 ) * + + = { \\cdot } ; ( 2 , -16 ) * + + = { \\cdot } ; \\end{xy}\\\\[4ex ] \\mbox{(b ) corran - picantin diagram for $ b(e , e , r)$ } \\end{array}\\ ] ]      the first author and picantin  @xcite obtained the following presentation for the braid group @xmath29 , the generators of which are _ braid reflections _ and which gives rise to a garside structure .",

    "the diagram shown in figure  [ fig : beer](b ) was proposed in  @xcite , as a type @xmath91-analogy to the coxeter graphs for the real reflection group case . in the diagram",
    ", there are @xmath5 nodes labeled @xmath52 , @xmath92 , that are tangent to a circle labeled 2 .",
    "whenever two nodes @xmath68 and @xmath69 are tangent to the circle , there is a relation of the form @xmath93 where @xmath94 and @xmath95 are the nodes immediately preceding @xmath68 and @xmath69 respectively on the circle .",
    "if two nodes @xmath68 and @xmath69 are neither connected by an edge nor tangent to the circle , then there is a relation of the form @xmath72 .",
    "naively , this appears like the _ dual _ presentation of @xmath32 ( on the generators @xmath52 ) combined with the _ classical _ presentation of @xmath96 ( on the generators @xmath97 ) .",
    "the group of graph automorphisms of the diagram is the cyclic group of order @xmath5 , which may be generated by the automorphism @xmath98 which rotates the circle in the positive direction by a turn of @xmath99 .",
    "this sends the node @xmath52 to the node @xmath100 for @xmath92 , and fixes the nodes @xmath101 for @xmath102 . by the symmetry of the presentation ,",
    "these diagram automorphisms give rise to automorphisms of the braid group @xmath29 as well as of the reflection group @xmath33 .",
    "these automorphisms send ( braid ) reflections to ( braid ) reflections .",

    "a braid @xmath146 is said to be _",
    "@xmath108-pure _ for @xmath147 if @xmath148 , where @xmath149 denotes the induced permutation of @xmath150 .",
    "let @xmath151 denote the subgroup of @xmath118 consisting of 1-pure braids , hence it is generated by @xmath152 .",
    "2 .   let @xmath153 be a subset of @xmath154 .",
    "an @xmath155-braid @xmath150 is said to be _ @xmath153-pure _ if @xmath150 is @xmath108-pure for each @xmath156 .",
    "it is said to be _",
    "@xmath153-straight _ if it is @xmath153-pure and it becomes trivial when we remove all the @xmath108-th strings for @xmath157 .",
    "the homomorphism @xmath158 measures the _ winding number _ around the first string of the other strings .",
    "in particular , @xmath159 and @xmath160 for all @xmath161 .",
    "@xmath162    for example , the braid in figure  [ fig : p - pure ] is @xmath163-pure , @xmath164-straight and @xmath165-straight , and has winding number 0 .",
    "notice that if @xmath166 , then a braid is @xmath153-pure if and only if it is @xmath153-straight , and that if @xmath167 , then @xmath153-pure braids are nothing more than pure braids in the usual sense and the identity braid is the only @xmath153-straight braid .",
    "it is well known that the braid group @xmath127 is isomorphic to the group of @xmath14-braids on an annulus and the braid group @xmath168 is isomorphic to the subgroup consisting of such braids with zero winding number  @xcite .",
    "equivalently , @xmath127 is isomorphic to the group of 1-pure @xmath155-braids on a disk and @xmath168 is isomorphic to the subgroup consisting of such braids with zero winding number around the first string . in this paper",
    ", we use the latter isomorphisms @xmath169    the embedding of @xmath142 into @xmath127 can be made explicit in the following way . consider a regular @xmath14-gon in the interior of a disk whose edges",
    "are labeled @xmath170 in clockwise order as in figure  [ fig : br - pic-1](a ) .",
    "suppose that one puncture is at the center and @xmath14 punctures are on the vertices of the @xmath14-gon .",
    "as mapping classes , the generator @xmath97 of @xmath171 is represented by a positive half dehn twist along @xmath172 .",

    ", we include a proof of theorem  [ binftyrpresthm ] .",
    "add new generators @xmath200 to shi s presentation which are defined inductively by @xmath201 the above relations are the same as @xmath202 for all @xmath193 , which is the same as the relation @xmath203 .",
    "therefore @xmath36 has the following presentation :    * generators : @xmath186 where @xmath187 and @xmath64 ; * relations : the usual braid relations on @xmath65 , along with + @xmath204    claim 1 assuming @xmath203 , the relation @xmath205 is equivalent to @xmath206 .",
    "@xmath206 is a special case of @xmath205 . assuming @xmath203 , every @xmath52",
    "is represented by a word in @xmath207 : for @xmath208 and @xmath209 , @xmath210 if we assume @xmath206 , then @xmath101 ( @xmath211 ) commutes with @xmath75 and @xmath74 , hence @xmath101 commutes with @xmath52 for any @xmath212 , which is the relation @xmath205 . therefore @xmath206 implies @xmath205 .",
    "claim 2 assuming @xmath203 , the relation @xmath213 is equivalent to @xmath214 .",
    "suppose that @xmath213 holds , that is , @xmath215 for all @xmath216 .",
    "notice that @xmath217 is a special case of @xmath213 .",
    "the following formula shows that @xmath218 also holds , where relations are applied to the underlined subwords .",
    "conversely , suppose that both @xmath217 and @xmath218 hold .",
    "by @xmath217 , we know that @xmath213 holds for @xmath220 .",
    "assume that @xmath213 holds for @xmath221 , which we denote by @xmath222 and @xmath223 , respectively .",
    "since @xmath224 we have @xmath225 by canceling @xmath226 from the right . hence @xmath213 holds for @xmath227 .",
    "similarly , we can show that @xmath213 holds also for @xmath228 . by induction , we conclude that @xmath213 holds for all @xmath193 .    from claims 1 and 2 ,",
    "the new presentation for @xmath36 is correct .",
    "the new presentation has the same generators as the original , as well as some conjugates of the originals . since it is the case for shi s presentation , adding the relations @xmath67 for all generators @xmath68 in the new presentation gives a presentation of the reflection group @xmath34 . since conjugates of reflections are reflections , the generators of this presentation are all reflections .",
    "brou , malle and rouquier  @xcite introduced the following presentation of @xmath1 :    * generators : @xmath229 where @xmath230 ; * relations : the usual braid relations on @xmath65 , along with + @xmath231    furthermore , a presentation for the reflection group @xmath232 is obtained by adding the relations @xmath233 , @xmath234 and @xmath235 for @xmath236 , and the generators are then all reflections .",
    "this presentation is usually illustrated by the diagram in figure  [ fig : bdeer](a ) ( note the similarity to the diagram for @xmath29 in figure  [ fig : beer](a ) ) . adding the relation @xmath237 to the above presentation gives the bmr presentation for @xmath29 , thus defining an epimorphism from @xmath1 to @xmath29 .",
    "@xmath238    in the case @xmath239 , type @xmath240 is precisely type @xmath126 .",
    "the above presentation is claimed in  @xcite as valid for @xmath241 ( probably to avoid doubling up for the type @xmath126 presentation ) .",
    "however it is indeed valid in the @xmath239 case as well . in this case , the bmr relation @xmath242 becomes @xmath243 , hence @xmath74 is a superfluous generator .",
    "if we remove @xmath74 from the set of generators and replace every occurrence of @xmath74 in the defining relations with @xmath244 , then the bmr presentation is reduced to the presentation of type @xmath126 , under the correspondence @xmath245 , @xmath246 and @xmath247 for @xmath248 .    in this article ,",
    "when we speak of the bmr - presentation , it will be implicit that @xmath249 and @xmath250 .",
    "we propose a new presentation for @xmath1 which makes clear the decomposition of @xmath1 as a semidirect product of @xmath36 and an infinite cyclic group .",

    "the action of @xmath269 is illustrated by a curved arrow labeled @xmath5 , describing the relation @xmath270 .",
    "as long as @xmath271 , @xmath272 . the parameter @xmath15 only makes an appearance when it comes to the reflection group @xmath9 . as described in  @xcite ,",
    "adding the relations @xmath233 and @xmath67 for all the other generators @xmath68 to the brou - malle - rouquier presentation of @xmath1 gives a presentation for the complex reflection group @xmath9 .",
    "the generators are all reflections , of order @xmath273 except @xmath269 which is of order @xmath15 .    the generators of the new presentation of @xmath260 are those of the brou - malle - rouquier presentation together with some conjugates of them .",
    "thus , as it is the case in  @xcite , adding the relations @xmath274 and @xmath67 for all the other generators @xmath68 to the new presentation of @xmath1 gives rise to a new presentation for the reflection group @xmath9 , where the generators are all reflections .",

    ", we conclude that @xmath262 holds for all @xmath193 .      in this subsection",
    ", we show that the new presentations of @xmath36 and @xmath1 give rise to quasi - garside structures .",
    "garside structures were defined by dehornoy and paris  @xcite , in which the strategy and results of garside  @xcite , deligne  @xcite , brieskorn and saito  @xcite still hold .",
    "a garside structure provides tools for calculating in the group , for solving word and conjugacy problems , as well as for giving certain information about the group ( such as being torsion - free ) . for a detailed description ,",
    "see  @xcite .",
    "we use the definition in  @xcite .",
    "a monoid @xmath333 is said to be _ quasi - garside _ if the following conditions are satisfied :    1 .",
    "@xmath333 is _",
    "atomic_that is , for every @xmath334 , the number of factors in a product equal to @xmath335 is bounded ; 2 .",
    "@xmath333 is left- and right - cancellative ; 3 .",
    "@xmath333 is a lattice with respect to each of the orders defined by left divisibility and by right divisibility ; 4 .",
    "@xmath333 has a _ garside element _",
    "@xmath336 for which the set of left divisors equals the set of right divisors , and this set generates @xmath333 .",
    "a quasi - garside monoid satisfies ore s conditions  @xcite , and thus embeds in its group of fractions .",
    "let @xmath333 be a quasi - garside monoid with garside element @xmath336 , and let @xmath6 be the group of fractions of @xmath333 .",
    "we identify the elements of @xmath333 and their images in @xmath6 .",
    "the pair @xmath337 is called a _ quasi - garside structure _ on @xmath6 , and the triple @xmath338 or just simply @xmath6 is called a _ quasi - garside group_. the quasi - garside monoid @xmath333 of @xmath6 is often denoted by @xmath339 .",
    "when the set of left divisors of the garside element @xmath336 is finite , the word ` quasi ' may be dropped for quasi - garside .    if the monoid @xmath333 is defined by a ( positive ) presentation with",
    "_ homogeneous _ relations  that is , for every relation , the left and right hand sides have equal length in the generators  then the first condition of being atomic is immediately satisfied , with the bound for the number of factors in a product equal to @xmath335 being precisely the number of generators in an expression for @xmath335 ( since this number is the same for all expressions for @xmath335 ) .",
    "this is always the case in the presentations we consider here .",
    "for the second and third conditions of being cancellative and being a lattice , we introduce the notions of complementedness and completeness of dehornoy  @xcite .",
    "let @xmath333 be a monoid defined by a positive presentation @xmath340 .",
    "let @xmath341 denote the free monoid generated by @xmath65 , and let @xmath342 denote the empty word .    for words",
    "@xmath46 , @xmath343 on @xmath344 , we say that @xmath46 _ right - reverses _ to @xmath343 , denoted @xmath345 , if @xmath343 is obtained from @xmath46 ( iteratively )    * either by deleting some subword @xmath346 for @xmath347 , * or by replacing some subword @xmath348 for @xmath349 with a word @xmath350 such that @xmath351 is a relation of @xmath352 .    for any @xmath353",
    ", @xmath354 implies that @xmath355 in @xmath333 .",
    "the presentation @xmath356 of @xmath333 is said to be    1 .",
    "_ right - complemented _ if for any @xmath357 , @xmath352 has at most one relation of the form @xmath358 and no relation of the form @xmath359 ; 2 .   _",
    "right - complete _ if for any @xmath353 , @xmath355 in @xmath333 implies @xmath354 .",
    "the left versions of the above notions are defined symmetrically . in this subsection",
    ", several notions have a left and a right version . without ` left ' or ` right ' , we assume both versions .",
    "for instance , `` @xmath333 is cancellative '' means `` @xmath333 is left- and right - cancellative '' .",
    "let @xmath360 , @xmath361 , @xmath362 and @xmath363 be the monoids defined by the presentations in theorems  [ beerpresthm ] , [ binftyrpresthm ] and  [ new - pre - deer ] and the presentation in   on page  , respectively .",
    "it is known that @xmath360 and @xmath363 are garside . in the remaining of this subsection",
    ", we will show that @xmath361 and @xmath362 are quasi - garside .",
    "the brou - malle - rouquier presentation for @xmath1 does not give rise to a quasi - garside structure for all @xmath30 .",
    "( notice that when @xmath239 , the group itself is a garside group because @xmath364 . )",
    "assume that the monoid defined by the presentation is quasi - garside .",
    "both @xmath365 and @xmath366 are common right multiples of @xmath73 and @xmath74 , hence @xmath367 is also a common right multiple of @xmath73 and @xmath74 , where @xmath368 denotes the left gcd .",
    "however @xmath369 is not a right multiple of @xmath74 , which is a contradiction .",
    "the same argument shows that shi s presentation for @xmath36 does not give rise to a quasi - garside structure .",
    "since the presentation of @xmath361 is homogeneous , the monoid is atomic .",
    "the conditions of being cancellative and a lattice can be checked by using complementedness and completeness .",
    "[ lem : deh03 ] ( * ? ? ? * corollary 6.2 and propositions 3.3 , 6.7 and 6.10 ) let @xmath333 be a monoid defined by a complemented and complete presentation with @xmath65 the set of generators . then the following hold .    1",
    ".   the monoid @xmath333 is cancellative .",
    "2 .   suppose that there exists @xmath370 such that @xmath371 and for any @xmath372 there exist @xmath373 with @xmath374 in @xmath333 .",
    "then @xmath333 admits right lcm s .",
    "3 .   suppose that there exists @xmath375 such that @xmath376 and for any @xmath377 there exist @xmath378 with @xmath379 in @xmath333 .",
    "then @xmath333 admits left lcm s .",
    "the presentation of @xmath361 is complemented . as for completeness , the cases to be considered are identical with those for @xmath360 ( figures 7 and 8 in  @xcite ) , hence it can be checked in a manner entirely analogous to that for @xmath360 given in @xcite . in that paper ,",
    "the presentation of @xmath360 was shown to be complete by using the cube condition on all triples of generators .",
    "therefore we have the following corollary by lemma  [ lem : deh03 ] .",
    "[ cor : cancel ] the monoid @xmath361 is cancellative .",
    "next , we will find sets @xmath370 and @xmath375 satisfying the conditions in lemma  [ lem : deh03 ] . define a map @xmath380 b_1 & \\mapsto & t_1 t_0 \\\\[1ex ] b_i & \\mapsto & s_{i+1 } \\quad \\mbox{for \\ $ 2\\le i\\le r-1$}. \\end{array}\\ ] ] it is easy to see that @xmath381 is a well - defined monoid homomorphism because the defining relations in @xmath382 can be realized by the relations in @xmath361 .",
    "for example , @xmath383 holds in @xmath361 ( see the proof of theorem  [ binftyrpresthm ] ) , hence @xmath384 holds in @xmath361 .",
    "we remark that @xmath381 is injective . to see this , consider the composition with the morphism from @xmath36 to @xmath385 which maps @xmath52 to @xmath137 for @xmath193 and @xmath101 to @xmath386 for @xmath236 .",
    "the composition is the well - known embedding of @xmath382 into @xmath387 which maps @xmath129 to @xmath388 and @xmath389 to @xmath390 for @xmath391 .",
    "the classical garside element of the braid group @xmath392 , denoted by @xmath393 , is the lcm of the generators @xmath394 .",
    "it is a central element of @xmath382 , written as @xmath395    let @xmath396 be the image of @xmath393 under @xmath381",
    ". then @xmath397 has the factorization @xmath398 where @xmath399 .",
    "let @xmath400 and @xmath401 denote the sets of all left and right divisors of @xmath397 , respectively .",
    "[ garsideelt ] the element @xmath397 is a garside element of @xmath361 .",
    "that is , @xmath402 , and @xmath400 generates @xmath361 .",
    "we give the proof of the above proposition in  [ ssec : garsideelt ] .",
    "the set @xmath402 meets the needs of @xmath370 and @xmath375 in lemma  [ lem : deh03 ] .",
    "therefore @xmath361 admits lcm s .",
    "it is easy to see that if a cancellative monoid admits lcm s then it admits gcd s .",
    "( for example , see lemma 2.23 in  @xcite ) .",
    "so far , we have shown that the monoid @xmath361 satisfies all the conditions in the definition of quasi - garside monoids .",
    "[ thm : garside - infty ] the presentation for @xmath36 in theorem  [ binftyrpresthm ] gives rise to a quasi - garside structure , where @xmath361 is the quasi - garside monoid and @xmath397 is a garside element .",
    "we will see in  [ ssec : embed_bdeer_br ] that the braid group @xmath36 is isomorphic to the affine braid group @xmath142 . in  @xcite , digne proposed a dual presentation of @xmath142 which gives a quasi - garside structure .",
    "this is different from the quasi - garside structure on @xmath403 given in theorem  [ thm : garside - infty ] .",
    "recall from corollary  [ bdeerthm ] that @xmath404 where @xmath405 is an infinite cycle group . from the presentation for @xmath406 in theorem",
    "[ new - pre - deer ] , @xmath264 acts on @xmath361 by @xmath407 and @xmath408 for @xmath193 and @xmath236 .",
    "from  [ ssec : garside_binfty ] , @xmath409 is a quasi - garside group . on the other hand , @xmath410 is a garside group , where @xmath411 .",
    "picantin  @xcite showed that the crossed product of garside monoids is a garside monoid .",
    "for semidirect products which are a special case of crossed products , it was directly proved in  @xcite .",
    "[ thm : lee07 ] let @xmath412 and @xmath413 be quasi - garside groups . if @xmath414 is an action of @xmath6 on @xmath415 and @xmath416 is fixed under @xmath414 , then @xmath417 is a quasi - garside group .",
    "theorem 4.1 in @xcite is indeed stated not for quasi - garisde groups but for garside groups , but its proof does not use finiteness of divisors of @xmath418 or @xmath416 . hence the above lemma is true .    since @xmath419 , the garside element @xmath397 of @xmath361",
    "is fixed under the action of @xmath264 .",
    "applying lemma  [ thm : lee07 ] , we have the following result .",
    "the presentation for @xmath1 in theorem  [ new - pre - deer ] gives rise to a quasi - garside structure on the imprimitive braid group @xmath404 , where @xmath420 is the quasi - garside monoid and @xmath421 is a garside element .",
    "indeed , @xmath422 is a garside element for any positive exponents @xmath423 and @xmath424 . a better choice would be @xmath425 because it is the generator of the center of @xmath1 .",
    "similarly @xmath426 is also a good choice .",
    "however , if @xmath427 , then @xmath428 does not have a central power .      when @xmath77 , the assertion is obvious .",
    "hence we assume @xmath141 .",

    "[ lem : cp ] let @xmath333 be a cancellative monoid and let @xmath468 . if there is an automorphism @xmath469 of @xmath333 such that @xmath470 for all @xmath471 , then the set of left divisors of @xmath472 is the same as the set of right divisors of @xmath472 .",
    "now , we are ready to show that @xmath397 is a garside element",
    ".    since each @xmath389 ( @xmath439 ) is a left divisor of @xmath393 in @xmath382 , @xmath473 and @xmath474 are left divisors of @xmath397 in @xmath429 .",
    "since each @xmath52 ( @xmath475 ) is a left divisor of @xmath474 , the set of left divisors of @xmath397 contains @xmath476 , hence it generates @xmath361 . by corollary  [ cor :",
    "cancel ] and lemmas  [ lem : lambda_balanced ] and [ lem : cp ] , the set of left divisors of @xmath397 equals the set of right divisors of @xmath397 .",
    "consequently , @xmath397 is a garside element .",
    "in this section , we explore some properties of @xmath1 by using the interpretation of @xmath1 as a geometric braid group .",
    "in  @xcite , brou , malle and rouquier constructed an isomorphism from @xmath123 to @xmath127 and an embedding of @xmath1 into @xmath127 .",
    "this subsection begins with reviewing them in our setting .",
    "consider the braid group @xmath123 . by putting @xmath239 to the relation @xmath477 of @xmath1 in theorem  [ new - pre - deer ]",
    ", we have @xmath478 for @xmath193 , hence for every @xmath193 @xmath479 then it is straightforward to simplify the presentation of @xmath123 in theorem  [ new - pre - deer ] to the presentation illustrated by the diagram in figure  [ fig : typeb ] . notice that it is the same as the diagram for @xmath127 in figure  [ fig :",
    "typeab](b ) , where @xmath129 and @xmath130 are replaced with @xmath269 and @xmath75 , respectively , and @xmath389 is replaced with @xmath97 for each @xmath248 . therefore the groups @xmath123 and @xmath127 are isomorphic by the following map . @xmath480",
    "z & \\mapsto & b_1 & \\\\[1ex ] t_i & \\mapsto & b_1^{-i } b_2 b_1^i & ( i\\in{\\mathbb z } ) \\\\[1ex ] s_j & \\mapsto & b_j & ( 3\\leq j \\leq r ) \\end{array}\\ ] ]    @xmath481    in  [ ssec : maps_bdeer ] , we saw that @xmath36 is a subgroup of @xmath123 , generated by @xmath482 where @xmath483 and @xmath484 .",
    "similarly , using the map @xmath485 which embeds @xmath1 into @xmath123 as a subgroup of index @xmath5 by sending @xmath269 ( of @xmath1 ) to @xmath486 ( of @xmath123 ) , we have that @xmath1 is isomorphic to a subgroup of @xmath123 generated by @xmath487 .",
    "these embeddings can be summarized as follows .",
    "@xmath488    [ bbr ]    1 .",
    "the braid group @xmath1 is isomorphic to the subgroup of @xmath127 of index @xmath5 generated by @xmath489 .",
    "the braid group @xmath36 is isomorphic to the subgroup of @xmath127 generated by @xmath490 .    the first statement of the above proposition is proposition  3.8 in  @xcite .",
    "the following is a direct consequence of the fact that @xmath1 is a finite index subgroup of @xmath127 and that @xmath127 is a garside group .",
    "@xmath1 has a finite @xmath491 , and is biautomatic .",
    "in particular , the word and conjugacy problems in @xmath1 are solvable .",
    "every garside group is biautomatic  @xcite and has a finite @xmath492  @xcite .",
    "any finite index subgroup of a biautomatic group is biautomatic , and the word and conjugacy problems are solvable in biautomatic groups  @xcite .",
    "it is obvious that any finite index subgroup of a group with a finite @xmath492 has a finite @xmath492 .",
    "since @xmath127 is a garside group and @xmath1 is a subgroup of @xmath127 of index @xmath5 , we are done .",
    "recall that @xmath493 and that @xmath494 is defined by @xmath159 and @xmath495 for @xmath496 . under the identification @xmath497 ,",
    "the homomorphism @xmath498 in the the exact sequence in  [ ssec : maps_bdeer ] is the same as the winding number @xmath494 .",
    "hence we have the following commutative diagram , where the rows are exact .",

    "the next proposition will be used in the study of discreteness of translation numbers ( in  [ ssec : tran ] ) and classification of periodic elements ( in  [ sec : periodelt ] ) .",
    "[ prop : conj ] the embedding @xmath535 induces a finite - to - one map on the sets of conjugacy classes .",
    "more precisely , for @xmath536 , @xmath537 and @xmath538 are conjugate in @xmath123 if and only if @xmath150 is conjugate to @xmath539 in @xmath1 for some @xmath540 .",
    "using corollary  [ cor : geobr ] , we identify @xmath123 and @xmath1 with @xmath151 and @xmath541 , respectively .",
    "let @xmath536 .",

    "let @xmath546 .",
    "then @xmath547 as @xmath548 , and @xmath549 therefore @xmath150 is conjugate to @xmath539 in @xmath1 .      the following are well - known results on the uniqueness of roots in braid groups .    1 .",
    "( gonzlez - meneses @xcite ) let @xmath150 and @xmath472 be elements of @xmath120 such that @xmath550 for some nonzero integer @xmath39",
    ". then @xmath150 and @xmath472 are conjugate in @xmath120 .",
    "( bardakov  @xcite , kim and rolfsen  @xcite ) let @xmath150 and @xmath472 be pure braids in @xmath120 such that @xmath550 for some nonzero integer @xmath39",
    ". then @xmath150 and @xmath472 are equal .",
    "3 .   ( lee and lee  @xcite )",
    "let @xmath6 be one of the braid groups of types @xmath119 , @xmath126 , @xmath551 and @xmath552 . if @xmath553 are such that @xmath550 for some nonzero integer @xmath39 , then @xmath150 and @xmath472 are conjugate in @xmath6 .",
    "the first of these was conjectured by makanin  @xcite in the early seventies , and proved by gonzlez - meneses .",
    "the second was initially proved by bardakov by combinatorial arguments , and it follows easily from the biorderability of pure braids by kim and rolfsen .",
    "the third result is a generalization of the other two and comes from the following theorem , by viewing the braid groups of types @xmath126 , @xmath551 and @xmath554 as subgroups of @xmath118 consisting of partially pure braids .",
    "[ thm : uniqueroot ] let @xmath153 be a subset of @xmath154 with @xmath555 .",
    "let @xmath150 and @xmath472 be @xmath153-pure @xmath155-braids such that @xmath550 for some nonzero integer @xmath39 .",
    "then there exists a @xmath153-straight @xmath155-braid @xmath184 with @xmath556 and @xmath557 .    applying theorem  [ thm : uniqueroot ] to @xmath558-pure @xmath155-braids , and using the isomorphisms in corollary  [ cor : geobr ] , we obtain the following uniqueness of roots up to conjugacy in @xmath1 and @xmath36 .",
    "let @xmath559 be such that @xmath550 for some nonzero integer @xmath39",
    ". then @xmath150 and @xmath472 are conjugate in @xmath1 .",
    "furthermore , a conjugating element @xmath184 can be chosen from the subgroup @xmath36 so that @xmath543 .    if @xmath560 are such that @xmath550 for some nonzero integer @xmath39 , then @xmath150 and @xmath472 are conjugate in @xmath37 .",
    "* question .",
    "*  does the uniqueness of roots up to conjugacy hold in @xmath29 and in the braid groups of real reflection groups of types other than @xmath119 , @xmath126 , @xmath3 and @xmath561 ?",
    "translation numbers , introduced by gersten and short  @xcite , are quite useful since it has both algebraic and geometric aspects . for a finitely",
    "generated group @xmath6 and a finite set @xmath562 of semigroup generators for @xmath6 , the _ translation number _ of an element @xmath563 with respect to @xmath562 is defined by @xmath564 where @xmath565 denotes the minimal word - length in the alphabet @xmath562 .",
    "when @xmath566 is a set of group generators , @xmath567 and @xmath568 indicate @xmath569 and @xmath570 , respectively .",
    "kapovich  @xcite and conner  @xcite suggested the following notions : a finitely generated group @xmath6 is said to be    1 .   _ translation separable _",
    "if for some ( and hence for any ) finite set @xmath562 of semigroup generators for @xmath6 the translation numbers of non - torsion elements are strictly positive ; 2 .   _",
    "translation discrete _ if it is translation separable and for some ( and hence for any ) finite set @xmath562 of semigroup generators for @xmath6 the set @xmath571 has 0 as an isolated point ; 3 .",
    "_ strongly translation discrete _ if it is translation separable and for some ( and hence for any ) finite set @xmath562 of semigroup generators for @xmath6 and for any real number @xmath14 the number of conjugacy classes @xmath572=\\{h^{-1}gh : h\\in g\\}$ ] with @xmath573 is finite .",
    "( the translation number is constant on each conjugacy class . )",
    "there are several results on translation numbers in geometric and combinatorial groups .",
    "biautomatic groups are translation separable  @xcite .",
    "word hyperbolic groups are strongly translation discrete , and moreover , the translation numbers in a word hyperbolic group are rational with uniformly bounded denominators  @xcite . artin groups of finite type are translation discrete  @xcite .",
    "garside groups are strongly translation discrete , and the translation numbers are rational with uniformly bounded denominators  @xcite .",
    "translation numbers of the braid groups @xmath36 and @xmath1 have the following properties .",
    "the braid group @xmath36 is translation discrete , and the braid group @xmath1 is strongly translation discrete .",
    "it is known that a subgroup of a translation discrete group is translation discrete  @xcite . since @xmath364 is strongly translation discrete  @xcite and since @xmath1 and @xmath36 are subgroups of @xmath123 , the groups @xmath1 and @xmath36 are translation discrete .",
    "let @xmath574 and @xmath575 . identify @xmath6 and @xmath576 with @xmath151 and @xmath514 , respectively .",
    "choose a finite set of generators , say @xmath562 , for @xmath576 .",
    "then @xmath577 is a finite set of generators for @xmath6 .",
    "choose any real number @xmath14 , and let @xmath578 notice that for any @xmath579 , @xmath580 , hence @xmath581 therefore @xmath582 . because @xmath6 is strongly translation discrete , there are finitely many conjugacy classes in @xmath583 .",
    "hence there are finitely many conjugacy classes in @xmath584 by proposition  [ prop : conj ] .",
    "an element @xmath150 in a braid group is said to be _ periodic _ if it has a central power . in this subsection",
    ", we classify periodic elements in @xmath1 . here",
    "the group @xmath1 is regarded as a subgroup of the braid group @xmath118 .",
    "the center of the artin braid group @xmath118 is an infinite cyclic group generated by @xmath524 , where @xmath585 .",
    "it is a classical theorem of brouwer , kerkjrt and eilenberg  @xcite that an @xmath155-braid is periodic if and only if it is conjugate to a power of either @xmath586 or @xmath342 , where @xmath587 and @xmath588 .",
    "see figure  [ fig : epsilon](a , b ) .",
    "the center of @xmath589 is also the infinite cyclic group generated by @xmath524 , and every periodic element of @xmath127 is conjugate to a power of @xmath342 .",
    "@xmath590{braid - delta.eps } & \\qquad & \\includegraphics[scale=.8]{braid - epsilon.eps } & \\qquad & \\includegraphics[scale=.8]{braid - epsilon1.eps}\\\\ \\mbox{(a ) the braid $ \\delta$ } & & \\mbox{(b ) the braid $ \\varepsilon$ } & & \\mbox{(c ) the braid $ \\varepsilon_1 $ } \\end{array}\\ ] ]    similar statements hold for the braid groups of other finite types and the braid group @xmath29 .",
    "for example , see  @xcite .",
    "bessis  @xcite explored many important properties of periodic elements in the context of braid groups of complex reflection groups .",

    "the converse direction is obvious .",

    "we recall the results of bessis  @xcite on periodic elements in the braid groups associated with _",
    "well - generated _ complex reflection groups .",
    "the reflection group @xmath9 is _ not _ well - generated .",
    "however we will see that bessis results hold for @xmath1 except the existence of the dual garside element @xmath586 .",
    "let @xmath6 be a complex reflection group on @xmath7 .",
    "let @xmath634 be degrees of @xmath6 and @xmath635 be codegrees of @xmath6 .",
    "the largest degree @xmath636 is called the _ coxeter number _ of @xmath6 , which we denote by @xmath472 .",
    "an integer @xmath423 is called a _ regular number _ if there exist an element @xmath563 and a complex @xmath423-th root @xmath637 of unity such that @xmath638 , where @xmath639 is the complement in @xmath7 of the reflecting hyperplanes of @xmath6 .",
    "the complex reflection group @xmath6 is called _ well - generated _ if @xmath6 can be generated by @xmath14 reflections .",
    "it is known that @xmath6 is well - generated if and only if @xmath6 is a _ duality group _ , i.e. , @xmath640 for all @xmath523 .",
    "the following theorem collects bessis results on periodic elements in braid groups ; see lemma 6.11 and theorems 1.9 , 8.2 , 12.3 , 12.5 in @xcite .",
    "the equivalence between ( a ) and ( b ) in the theorem was proved by lehrer and springer  @xcite and by lehrer and michel  @xcite , and it does not require well - generatedness of the complex reflection group @xmath6 .",
    "[ thm : bes06a ] let @xmath6 be an irreducible well - generated complex reflection group , with degrees @xmath641 , codegrees @xmath642 and coxeter number @xmath472 .",
    "then its braid group @xmath643 admits the dual garside structure with garside element @xmath586 , and the following hold .    1 .",
    "the element @xmath644 is central in @xmath643 and lies in the pure braid group of @xmath6 .",

    "the center of @xmath643 is a cyclic group generated by @xmath646 .",
    "3 .   let @xmath423 be a positive integer , and let @xmath647 then @xmath648 ,",

    "+ moreover , the @xmath423-th root of @xmath650 , if exists , is unique up to conjugacy in @xmath643 .",
    "the coxeter groups of types @xmath651 and the complex reflection group @xmath33 are all irreducible well - generated complex reflection groups .",
    "but @xmath9 is _ not _ well - generated , hence the above theorem can not be applied .",

    "[ atilde - type - presentation ] the group @xmath701 for @xmath26 , @xmath30 and @xmath141 has the following presentation :    * generators : @xmath702 ; * relations : + @xmath703    where @xmath704 . furthermore , on adding the relations @xmath275 and @xmath144 for all @xmath523 , a presentation for the reflection group @xmath9 is obtained , where the generators are all reflections .",
    "the first author gratefully acknowledges the support of a european union _ marie curie _ fellowship while this work was carried out .",
    "the second author was supported by basic science research program through the national research foundation of korea ( nrf ) funded by the ministry of science , ict & future planning ( nrf-2012r1a1a3006304 ) .",
    "the third author was supported by basic science research program through the national research foundation of korea ( nrf ) funded by the ministry of education ( nrf-2013r1a1a2007523 ) ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we obtain new presentations for the imprimitive complex reflection groups of type @xmath0 and their braid groups @xmath1 for @xmath2 . </S>",
    "<S> diagrams for these presentations are proposed . </S>",
    "<S> the presentations have much in common with coxeter presentations of real reflection groups . </S>",
    "<S> they are positive and homogeneous , and give rise to quasi - garside structures . </S>",
    "<S> diagram automorphisms correspond to group automorphisms . </S>",
    "<S> the new presentation shows how the braid group @xmath1 is a semidirect product of the braid group of affine type @xmath3 and an infinite cyclic group . </S>",
    "<S> elements of @xmath1 are visualized as geometric braids on @xmath4 strings whose first string is pure and whose winding number is a multiple of @xmath5 . </S>",
    "<S> we classify periodic elements , and show that the roots are unique up to conjugacy and that the braid group @xmath1 is strongly translation discrete .    </S>",
    "<S> _ keywords _ : complex reflection group ; braid group ; garside group ; periodic element ; translation number . </S>",
    "<S> + _ 2010 mathematics subject classification _ : primary 20f55 , 20f36 ; secondary 20f05 , 20f10 , 03g10 + </S>"
  ]
}
